meeting_annotations.speaker: Fikile Brushett
meeting_annotations.transcript: So um when I when I think about this um type of problem, um I think about sort of the stuff that we've thought about for catalysis um across different driving forces for years. So selectivity, stability, um and and durability. Um and whether that's for photocatalyst, thermocatalyst or electrocatalyst, that's really what ultimately defines whether something's going to be successful or not. And then I think depending upon the way the driving force is delivered, um be it sunlight photo, um be it, you know, thermo so heat, uh be it electro, so, you know, potential, that determines sort of the way the catalyst can be used, so the way it's structured, think about reactor design, right? There's ways you design reactors for thermocatalysts that you couldn't really design for so easily for say photocatalysts, right? Um, and once you start getting into sort of the design or how these materials can be used, that's when transport starts to play a significant role in terms of sort of driving this along. So I I tend to think that you know, there might be a generalized theme um across these different driving forces and if you build from the catalyst and sort of build from catalyst to implementation. That that's an initial thought to kind of maybe get people going and feel one way or the other about it.
